III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & R 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirements;
Section staff qualifications.
Description (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Daily from April of 2024/August of 2024, Supervisor 1 went in the
bathroom with Youth A, forced her to undress, and touched Youth
A's private parts. Supervisor 1 tried to have sex with Youth A, but
Youth A refused. Youth A had to be physically violent with
Supervisor 1 or she would continue sexually abusing her.
Investigation Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the facility with
the MDHHS Worker 1 on 5/20/2025. He reported not being
aware of the allegations but will provide all requested information.
He reported Supervisor 1 was on medical leave, came back to
work and quit abruptly in the middle of a shift on 11/25/2024. He
reported Youth A was in the Freedom program (2/15/24-8/19/24)
but has since left and there are three youth still at the facility who
were in the program with Youth A. Administrator reported there is
no documentation of Youth A filing a complaint for sexual abuse,
however there was a complaint filed by Youth A in which staff
pushed Youth A, and this was investigated (2024SIC0001304).
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility with the
MDHHS Worker 1 on 5/20/2025. Youth B reported remembering
Youth A in the Freedom program and knows Youth A makes
complaints against staff. Youth B reported Youth A seemed to
have difficulty with adult figures and didn’t take redirection from
staff very well. Youth B reported Youth A struggled when staff
tried to calm Youth A down and was quick to make a complaint if
Youth A didn’t like what staff were telling Youth A. Youth B was
unable to report anything negative about Supervisor 1 and
indicated having a good relationship with Supervisor 1. Youth B
described Supervisor 1 as really cool, funny, and sweet while
being easy to get along with. Youth B reported Supervisor 1 was
called grandmother by most of the youth and was always making
sure youth were “safe and ok”. Youth B reported it was very rare
that Supervisor 1 would sit on the “wing” because Supervisor 1
was checking on youth, staff, and passing medication throughout
the shift. Youth B reported the showering process as only one
youth was allowed in the bathroom/shower at a time with the
2

exception of a youth on 100%. The 100% was described as staff
needing to have eyes on a youth at all times because of high
suicidal risk. Youth B reported staff would stand in the doorway
with the door open enough for staff to hear the youth in the
shower. In this way, staff were able to listen to the youth in the
shower and respond quickly if the youth was not responding to
verbal prompts. Youth B denied observing Supervisor 1 in a
bathroom alone with Youth A. Youth B reported feeling safe at the
facility.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility with the
MDHHS Worker 1 on 5/20/2025. Youth C reported remembering
Supervisor 1 and described her as an elder with blonde hair who
kept an eye on the youth and everyone got along with. Youth C
reported never hearing that any youth complained about
Supervisor 1, who was always appropriate. Youth C reported
feeling safe and well cared for at the program. Youth C reported
remembering Youth A who Youth C described as being
disrespectful and unable to get along with staff at times. Youth C
reported never hearing Youth A make a complaint about
Supervisor 1. Youth C denied observing Supervisor 1 in a
bathroom alone with Youth A. Youth C described the bathroom
process as only 1 youth at a time was allowed in the
bathroom/shower unless the youth was on a 100%. Youth C
described the process of bathroom use for youth on the 100% in
the same way Youth B described the process.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility with the
MDHHS Worker 1 on 5/20/2025. Youth D reported Supervisor 1
was a favorite staff among the youth in the Freedom program.
Youth D reported Supervisor 1 would do rounds and go where she
was needed. Supervisor 1 was attentive to the youth and Youth D
didn’t remember any youth making a complaint against Supervisor
1. Youth D reported remembering Youth A and described Youth A
as someone who made complaints to everyone about everyone.
Youth A started problems and would give false information about
situations. Youth D reported if Youth A didn’t like what staff were
doing, Youth A would tell everyone that staff did something to
Youth A. Youth D reported staff always worked to keep the youth
safe. Youth D denied observing Supervisor 1 in a bathroom alone
with Youth A. Youth D described the bathroom/shower procedure
as the same as Youth B and Youth C with only 1 youth allowed in
the bathroom at a time and staff standing in the hallway. Youth D
described the 100% procedure the same as Youth B and Youth C.
Youth D reported staff might be in the bathroom standing at the
3

sink while the 100% youth is in the shower (with a curtain) and not
looking at the youth in the shower.
Staff 1 was interviewed via video with the MDHHS Worker 1
on 5/30/2025. Staff 1 reported working as a “Youth and Family
specialist” for the past three years at the facility. She reported
working with Supervisor 1 and Youth A in the Freedom program in
2024. She reported being aware of Youth A making general
complaints against floor staff but not being aware of any
inappropriate behavior by staff. Staff 1 reported Supervisor 1 was
positive with the youth and never witnessing Supervisor 1
observing or helping with youth showers. Supervisor 1’s primary
job was passing medication and assigning staff to different units.
Staff 1 reported the shower procedure the same as the youth
interviewed and reported the 100% procedure as staff standing in
the doorway with their backs to the youth.
Staff 2 was interviewed via video with the MDHHS Worker 1
on 5/30/2025. Staff 2 reported working as a “Youth and Family
specialist” for the past year and having contact with both
Supervisor 1 and Youth A on the Freedom program. She reported
Youth A had a history of not liking someone and not wanting them
on the unit. Staff 2 reported never hearing about Youth A making
a complaint about staff being inappropriate with Youth A. Staff 2
reported Supervisor 1 would assign staff to different units, tell staff
when to take breaks, but never worked as a floor staff with the
youth. Staff 2 never heard complaints about Supervisor 1 and
Supervisor 1 was good in dealing with the youth. Staff 2 described
the shower procedure the same as other staff and youth
interviewed but added, staff would knock on the door and check a
youth (one at a time) in the bathroom/shower to ensure they were
safe. She also described the 100% procedure the same with staff
standing in the doorway.
Staff 3 was interviewed via video with the MDHHS Worker 1
on 5/30/2025. She reported working as a Youth Coach for the
past three and a half years and had contact with both Supervisor 1
and Youth A. She described Youth A as being an “aggressive
youth” but was unable to recall any complaints against staff except
when staff pushed Youth A (2024SIC0001304). She reported
Supervisor 1 was in charge of the whole building and there was
never any complaint of Supervisor 1 being inappropriate with any
youth. She reported never witnessing Supervisor 1 supervising a
youth taking a shower because Supervisor 1 was almost never on
the floor with the youth because of Supervisor 1’s other duties.
Supervisor 1 had a good reputation, and her duties included
4

paperwork, making sure staff were attentive to youth, and passing
medication.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed via video with the MDHHS
Worker 1 on 5/30/2025. He reported working as a Program
Manager for the past three and a half years and has worked with
both Youth A and Supervisor 1. He reported never receiving or
hearing about Youth A making a complaint about Supervisor 1
being inappropriate. He described Youth A as displaying random
outbursts but nothing violent. He reported believing Youth A may
have been restrained once or twice in the time Youth A was in the
program. Supervisor 2 reported Supervisor 1’s duties included
making sure staff are working and youth are safe. He reported
never witnessing Supervisor 1 supervising showers, but she would
make sure staff were providing the appropriate supervision during
showers. Supervisor 2 reported the bathroom/shower procedure
as other staff interviewed reported but added that only one youth
in the bathroom/shower at a time and if staff need to be in the
bathroom at the same time, then two staff are required to be in the
bathroom. Staff are not allowed in the bathroom with a youth
unless it is an emergency. He also described the 100% procedure
as the door must be open when the staff is in the bathroom.
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 6/10/25.
Complainant reported having no further information to add and
has “no reason to doubt Youth A’s report”.
Area Manager virtually attended a child advocacy center
(CAC) interview with Youth A on 06/26/2025. Youth A stated
she was present at the CAC today because she told her therapist
one of the staff members had sexually abused her. This staff
member told Youth A to go to the bathroom, shoved her against
the wall, tried to undress her and touched her inappropriately. This
occurred at Vista sometime in 2024, but she stated Youth A was
at the agency for three more months after this occurred, and the
staff member involved who did this was Supervisor 1. She
explained she was in her room watching TV when Supervisor 1
told Youth A to come into the staff bathroom, which is located on
the other side of the hall and is not a bathroom Youth A usually
goes to. Supervisor 1 then tried to undress Youth A, she told
Youth A to take off her clothes and then pulled on Youth A’s
clothes to take them off. Youth A stated Supervisor 1 threatened
her, and Youth A did not recall what Supervisor 1 said. After
Supervisor 1 threatened Youth A, Youth A stated she felt scared
and “took everything off”, which included her shirt, pants,
underwear and bra. Youth A stated Supervisor 1 pushed her
5

against the wall and pulled Youth A’s arm to her throat. Youth A
stated she was standing, and her legs were spread apart. After
Youth A removed her clothes, Supervisor 1 touched her private
parts (she uses her private part to “pee”), with her hands and
explained Supervisor 1 used her hands to rub her private body
and tried to stick her hand “in it”, Youth A stated this hurt. Youth A
stated Supervisor 1 had one hand to her neck and the other hand
touching her private body with her fingers. Youth A stated
someone then knocked on the door, unknown who, and
Supervisor 1 told her to put her clothes back on and she went
back to what she was doing previously in her bedroom. Youth A
stated she did not share a bedroom with another youth, and no
one saw her leave to go into the staff bathroom. Youth A stated
this was the first time something like this happened and it did not
happen again. Youth A stated no one else saw what occurred and
she did not tell anyone about this until she left the agency
because Supervisor 1 told her if she told anyone, she would kill
her, and Supervisor 1 told Youth A this before Youth A left the
staff bathroom. Youth A stated Supervisor 1 did not say anything
else to her during the incident.
Youth A reported that during an unknown date with an unknown
staff member, a staff had pushed Youth A over a piece of metal,
and she received a bruise on her back. Youth A stated no one
knew about this incident and no one else was present to witness
this incident. Youth A stated other staff hurt her physically by
pushing her around and punching her and staff only did this to her
and no one else. She did not recall dates or staff who pushed or
punched her, no further details were provided (investigated under
2024SIC0001304).
Youth A was asked clarifying questions and she stated she did not
recall any other youths present when the incident with Supervisor
1 occurred and stated she was reading before Supervisor 1 told
her to come to the staff bathroom. She stated after the incident,
she walked back to her bedroom by herself.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed via phone on 8/12/2025. She
reported knowing about the allegations but strongly denied them.
She reported not understanding why Youth A would choose
Supervisor 1 to make allegations against since Supervisor 1
reported they had a good relationship when Youth A was at the
facility. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A would attack other staff but
never Supervisor 1 and Supervisor 1 was able to de-escalate
Youth A when Youth A became dysregulated. Youth A took
Supervisor 1’s verbal redirection and even asked Supervisor 1 to
6

visit Youth A in Youth A’s new placement (Supervisor 1 never did
visit Youth A in the new placement). Supervisor 1 reported never
being in a bathroom with Youth A or any other youth because staff
should not be in the bathroom with a youth nor behind a closed
door with youth. Supervisor 1 reported staff will support her denial
because it never happened. When asked why she left the facility,
Supervisor 1 reported because of all the investigations it became
a horrible place to work, and she was tired of being attacked by
the youth.
Documents Reviewed:
11 Incident reports for Youth A:
• 6/16/24-Suicide Assessment. Supervisor 1 was requested
by Youth A and a suicidal assessment was completed. This
resulted in Youth A being transported to Children’s Hospital
by Supervisor 1.
• 6/26/24-Youth A attempting to break a lock, metal block off
the door, kicking and striking walls and doors. Youth A is
also documented as verbally attacking staff, hitting
windows, trying to tear down a ceiling panel, and
aggressively hitting herself in the face. Supervisor 1 is
documented as arriving and verbally de-escalating Youth A
privately in the bathroom. Youth A presented no further
issues.
• 6/28/24-Youth A became dysregulated and began attacking
staff during a group meeting. Youth A is documented as
throwing a chair at Supervisor 1 before beginning to calm
down. It is documented that once removed to another
room, Youth A re-escalated and required a restraint
involving Supervisor 1.
• 7/1/24-Youth A is documented as being upset because a
specific staff was not working that shift and Youth A wanted
that staff to be working. Youth A is also documented as
throwing items and cursing at staff. Youth A began to self-
harm and Supervisor 1 asked another staff to come and
assist. Youth A assaulted staff before beginning to regulate
her emotions.
• 7/9/24-Youth A is documented as verbally attacking staff
before physically attacking staff. Supervisor 1 is
documented as coming on the scene and attempting to
verbally de-escalate Youth A, but the attempt failed.
7

Supervisor 1 and another staff engaged in a Behavior
Management hold.
• 7/11/24-Youth A throwing games, markers and bingo chips
all over the floor at 11:18 am. Youth A is upset because
she is not able to watch a TV show when it was another
youth’s turn to pick the show. Supervisor 1 was called to
de-escalate Youth A and was successful in doing so.
• 7/29/24-Youth A was documented as hitting staff after
becoming dysregulated. Supervisor 1 and another staff
were involved in verbally de-escalation to help Youth A
calm down. They were successful and Supervisor 1
completed a suicidal assessment on Youth A and the
nursing staff were notified.
• There were four other incident reports that did not involve
Supervisor 1. There were 2 incidents where Youth A
threatened to get staff fired and 2 incidents when Youth A
attacked several staff, engaged in self-harming behaviors
and Law Enforcement was called because of Youth A’s
violent behaviors.
Case Report Dearborn Heights PD CR No: 250017670 dated
7/2/2025. This document outlines Law Enforcement’s investigation
into the charge of CSC 1st Degree with Supervisor 1. The report
identifies several inconsistencies in Youth A’s report of the
allegations involving Youth A’s location when the alleged incident
began (reported watching TV in her room but there are no TV’s in
bedrooms, watching TV with others which changed to sitting alone
in her room reading). The report also documents Youth A gave
very vague answers and was not forthcoming. It is documented
that Supervisor 1 reported a “great” relationship with Youth A and
Supervisor 1 was the staff called when Youth A became
dysregulated (physically and mentally abusive towards staff). It is
documented that Supervisor 1 believes the allegations are a result
of Youth A feeling abandoned because Supervisor 1 did not visit
Youth A at her new placement. Supervisor 1 denied the
allegations and stated never taking a youth to the bathroom
because the line staff would be responsible for that action if
needed.
HR file for Supervisor 1 was reviewed. Documentation indicates
Supervisor 1 was hired on 7/5/23 and there are two disciplinary
actions documented in the file. The first disciplinary action (verbal
warning) occurred on 4/1/24 and was the result of a policy
8

violation in regard to safety and supervision of clients. She
allowed clients to have items that were deemed contraband after
safety plans were communicated to all staff. The second is
documented as a written warning on 7/18/24 and involved
Supervisor 1 sending an email regarding a meeting after
Supervisor 1 was advised by Director that Director was going to
send out the email. Supervisor 1 was found to have sent the email
out to various employees. Documentation in the HR file indicates
Supervisor 1 quit employment on 11/25/24 after calling Human
Resources and informing them that she was “done”. Supervisor 1
is documented as taking her belongings and leaving the unit.
Documentation in the HR file also confirms Supervisor 1 was
current on her required trainings.
Vista Maria Residential Program Policy Client Observation
POL-005-020 dated 3/2016. This document is to ensure the
safety of all youth. The levels of observation are outlined with High
Level being described as 100% observation. If a youth is placed
on this level the staff must remain with the youth at all times and
document the youth’s behaviors and actions every 15-minutes.
Staff are not to leave the youth without replacement staff available
to provide uninterrupted observation. It is documented that youth
on 100% observation must have the observing staff sit in the
bathroom while the youth is meeting their personal needs.
Vista Maria Residential Program Policy Employee Behavior
022-114 dated 5/2021. This document outlines guiding principles
of acceptable and unacceptable employee behavior. Staff are
expected to conduct themselves in a positive, professional, and
respectful manner at all times. Prohibited behaviors are
documented and include, “engaging in any form of sexual or other
forms of harassing or bullying behavior”.
Walk-through:
A walk-through was completed at the facility. The facility is an
older building that has evidence of being in the process of having
repairs to the walls. They have plywood covering holes in the
walls until the scheduled repairs can be completed. Administrator
1 reported repairs have been scheduled. The facility is furnished
appropriately, especially in the bedroom areas and the plumbing is
in working order.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as evidenced by interviews with
staff, youth, and documentation reviews. There is no witnesses,
and all staff and additional youth interviewed did not give any
evidence of supporting the allegations. All youth interviewed
9

denied ever observing Supervisor 1 in a bathroom alone with
Youth A. It should be noted that Youth A had changed the
allegations from the initial of daily sexual abuse to only once
during the CAC interview and the Law Enforcement investigation
documents inconsistencies in Youth A report. Given Youth A’s
history of violence it appears doubtful that Youth A would accept
being intimidated by Supervisor 1.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical Assistance was provided in respect to ensuring staff
understand the importance of making sure they are not alone with
youth and have a secondary staff present. Staff should never be in
the youth’s bedroom or bathroom without the second staff for
support and staff should stay within camera view as much as
possible.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
